_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary
INTRODUCTION

The Empire Kosher Poultry facility utilizes anhydrous ammonia, CAS #7664-41-7, in its refrigeration process.  The substance is stored in a high-pressure receiver on the south- west corner of the facility.  The system is designed to store a maximum of 13,000 lbs of anhydrous ammonia.


ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

Empire Kosher Poultry, Inc. is committed to operating all of its' facilities in the safest possible condition to protect their employees, the public and the environment receptors located near the plant.  This commitment is demonstrated through the use of proper equipment, regular inspections, maintenance, and training of all persons that work with anhydrous ammonia.

The facilityA?s Manager of Safety and Risk Management maintains an Emergency Action Plan (EAP) on file. According to the EAP, facility employees responsible for responding to incidental releases of ammonia, all members of the Response Team have been trained to the Hazardous Materials Technician Level according to the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) standard 29 CFR 1910.120 -  Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response (Hazwoper). .  The facility employees have been trained on the use of personal protective equipment and maintenance procedures to ensure the continued safe operation of the system.

GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM STEPS

Empire Kosher Poultry uses employee/contractor training, standard operating procedures, pre-startup safety reviews, management of change procedures, hot work permit and auditing programs as the basis for its general release prevention program.  The facility has a preventative maintenance program, pipe and valve labeling program and inspection program that is related to the anhydrous ammonia refrigeration system.  The management and employees of Empire Kosher Poultry, Inc. are continually looking for ways to improve the safety of the system.

* The ammonia re

frigeration system is equipped with a number of safety and control devices that can be utilized in the event of a release or event involving the ammonia system.  

* Human factors are critical to the safe operation and maintenance of the anhydrous ammonia refrigeration system.  It is vital that all employees of Empire Kosher Poultry, Inc. have a general awareness of the anhydrous ammonia refrigeration system.     Training is provided to the following employee groups:
o New employees, Current employees, Operators, Contractors

* An important component of the prevention program is the mechanical integrity program, which includes routine maintenance inspections of the storage tanks and associated ammonia refrigeration equipment. The preventive maintenance program at Empire Kosher Poultry includes an inventory of the anhydrous ammonia refrigeration system that is based in the Maintenance Department on the PMC computerized work order system that identifies frequencies and tasks to maintains all refrigeration related equipment.

* The facility implements the use of a Pre-startup safety review (PSSR) to ensure that important considerations have been addressed before any anhydrous ammonia is introduced to the refrigeration system.  

* The management of change process at Empire Kosher Poultry was developed to ensure that proposed changes to the anhydrous ammonia refrigeration system are evaluated and approved before being implemented and that inadvertent or unintended changes are prevented.

* Empire Kosher Poultry's Contractors Qualifications program applies to all contractors and their employees that perform any type of work on or in the vicinity of the anhydrous ammonia system.  

* Empire Kosher Poultry Inc. conducts compliance audits of the prevention program once every three years in conjunction with the process safety management requirements. The most recent compliance audits were conducted in May of 2007.  .

* An accident investigation process is in place at Empire

Kosher to ensure a thorough review of any incidents relating to the ammonia refrigeration system, and any related corrective actions are implemented and evaluated.


FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

There have been no known accidental ammonia releases from the system that have resulted in either an on-site or off-site consequence.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The facilityA?s Manager of Safety and Risk Management maintains an Emergency Action Plan (EAP) on file. According to the EAP, facility employees responsible for responding to incidental releases of ammonia, all members of the Response Team have been trained to the Hazardous Materials Technician Level according to the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) standard 29 CFR 1910.120 -  Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response (Hazwoper).   The facility employees have been trained on the use of personal protective equipment and maintenance procedures to ensure the continued safe operation of the system

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Safety improvement is an on-going process at this facility.  Periodic inspections and evaluations are performed to assess the continued safe practices and operations.  There are no additional specific anhydrous ammonia safety recommendations for implementation at this time.
